With his credit, Vazha will begin a trade in fruits and vegetables. He plans to purchase fruits and vegetables at wholesale prices and then resell them from the counter near his house. This will increase the income of the family. The new business initiative, financed with the Kiva start-up loan, will significantly improve the living conditions of the family.

loans.use: to begin a trade in fruits and vegetables.

loans.name: Ediltrudes

texts.en: Ediltrudes is a 46-year-old woman from Panglao, Bohol. Ediltrudes has been engaged in selling coconut shells and hog raising for more than 15 years now. These are the sources of her income. Ediltrudes is asking for a loan worth PHP 17,000 to buy more coconut shells and additional piglets to raise. Through this loan she will be able to improve her business and eventually her income. Ediltrudes also plans on saving money for the reinvestment of the same business and to repay her loan on time.

loans.use: to buy more coconut shells and additional piglets to raise

loans.name: Faranges

texts.ru: Фарангесу 21 года. Она замужем и на воспитании имеет 1 сына. Фарангес с юных лет помогала маме с торговлей. Фарангес более 4 лет занимается самостоятельно купле продажей женской одежды на местом рынке. Вначале было трудно, у нее не была средства и мать помогла Фарангесу, одолжив в долг маленькую сумму. Постепенно она начала развевать свой бизнес. Спустя 2 года она вышла замуж и временно оставила бизнес, но так как ее муж получает маленькую зарплату и его зарплата не хватает для содержания семьи, она вновь начала заниматься бизнесом. Она хочет увеличить свой оборотный капитал и поэтому обратилась за займом в сумме 2500 долларов США. Она ждет вашу доброту.
texts.en:
Faranges is 21 years old. She is married and raising one son. Faranges has helped her mothers with trade since her early years. Faranges has for more than four years worked independently with buying and reselling women's clothing at the local market. In the beginning it was hard and she had no financial resources. Her mother helped her, lending her a small amount of money. Faranges started to develop her business step by step. 

After two years she got married and left her business, but as her husband receives a small salary and it is not enough for supporting the family, she again started a business. She would like to increase her working capital and therefore turned to us for a loan in the amount of 2,500 US dollar. She awaits your kindness.

loans.use: To buy woman clothes for increasing working capital

loans.name: Batkhuyag

texts.en: Mr. Batkhuyag, 35 years old, lives with his wife and three children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Recently, his wife gave birth to their third son. She has taken her maternity leave and is staying at home. He has been transporting goods within municipality for two years. He transports coals, vegetables and building materials in winter, autumn, spring and summer time. Before this transportation service, he had been rendering taxi services for six consecutive years. He is requesting a loan of 1000000 MNT to purchase a sofa and a computer for personal use. In the last three years, his family hasn't purchased any significant home appliances, so this year they have decided to purchase a sofa and a personal computer. The personal computer will be used by his children as a educational tool. The borrower is a very hardworking individual who strives for a better future.

loans.use: to purchase a sofa and a personal computer

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace is married with 2 children. She has received some schooling until the end of junior high school. Currently, Grace sells onions in Assiekie (which is near Takoradi). She has been involved in this industry for about 3 years now. Her husband works in construction. Grace's income goes towards helping her husband pay for the family's general expenses. Grace will use the loan to increase her existing stock of onions for sale. With the new profits from her expanded enterprise, Grace plans to develop her business further by venturing into newer markets.

loans.use: to increase her existing stock of onions for sale

loans.name: Diega

texts.en: Diega is a farmer from the town of Sikatuna, Bohol. She has been in the farming business since 2005. Diega is asking for a loan to buy fertilizer and pesticides for her farm. With this, she will be able to improve her farm and harvest. In the future, Diega hopes of making her business a success.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and pesticides for her farm

loans.name: Farida

texts.en:
Farida is married and has four children. Three of her children go to school.  She doesn’t take care of additional family members. She has a business selling sugar cane, and she has been in this business for six years. She resides in a rented house, and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses include rent and paying school fees for her children. 

She has applied for a loan of 500,000 Uganda shillings (UGX) from MCDT-SACCO. She will use the loan to buy more bundles of sugar cane to resell. She works at the market seven days out of every week and sells on a retail basis only. Her major business challenges include seasonality and thieves. She is aspiring to become a wholesaler, and also to build her own house.

loans.use: To buy more bundles of sugar cane

loans.name: Elmie

texts.en:
Elmie is a 31-year-old, married woman from Maribojoc, Bohol. She has been engaged in a furniture and carpentry business for more than five years, with her husband. This is the source of their income.

Elmie is asking for a loan, which she will use to buy additional wood, nails, varnish, and other supplies. Through this loan, they will be able to improve their furniture and carpentry business. Elmie has hopes of improving her livelihood and experiencing fullness of life.

loans.use: to buy additional wood, nails, varnish, and other supplies

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is a small-scale baker who bakes bread for sale in Asekie (near Takoradi). She has had some form of formal education, as she is a junior high school graduate.   

Mary is a widow and has one child. She has been working as a baker for close to three years. Her income is used in paying her utility bills and her child’s school fees. She plans on using her loan to purchase an increased quantity of flour and sugar. She hopes to use the profits from her enterprise to fulfill her dream of buying a bread stand, hence helping her sell from a fixed location in the future.

loans.use: to buy an increased quantity of flour and sugar to make her bread, thus allowing her to meet rising customer demands.

loans.name: Linda

texts.en: Linda  is married with two children. She has received some schooling til the end of primary school. Currently, Linda sells smoked fish in Hotopo (near Takoradi). She has been involved in this industry for about two years now. Her husband is a driver.  Linda's income goes towards helping her husband pay for the family's general expenses.  Linda will use the loan to increase her existing fish capacity. With the new profits from her expanded enterprise, Linda plans to develop her business further by venturing into newer markets.

loans.use: to increase her existing fish capacity.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Although she has received no prior formal education, Mary is an entrepreneur. She specializes in selling African print cloth and dresses in Hotopo (near Takoradi). She has been involved in this enterprise for three years.  

Mary is married and has four children. Her husband works as a painter. The proceeds from her business normally go towards helping her husband cover the family’s general expenses and pay their children’s school fees.  

Mary wants to use her loan to increase her current inventory levels, hence allowing her to sell greater quantities of African print cloth and dresses. 

In the long term, Mary plans to reinvest future profits into her business, thus helping her to expand and meet the needs of rising customer demands.

loans.use: to increase her current inventory levels, hence allowing her to sell greater quantities of African print cloth and dresses.

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en: For over ten years, Fatuma has operated a food stall business from her home to neighbors and passers-by. She faces the challenge of stiff competition from other food stall operators. With the KES 30,000 that she is requesting, Fatuma wants to pay school fees for her children who attend school. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business and she gives thanks for the opportunity granted.

loans.use: to pay school fees for her children who attend school.

loans.name: Ama

texts.en:
Due to difficult circumstances, Ama did not have access to any form of formal education, yet this has not stopped her from achieving her dream of becoming an entrepreneur. Currently, Ama sells sugar cane  in Asekie  (near Takoradi). She has been doing so for about three years. As a widow with six children, Ama uses all her income to feed and provide for her family. 

Ama will use the loan to purchase an increased amount of sugar cane, which will aid her in improving her overall sales. Ama wants to use the future profits from her expanded business to ensure that all her children are able to receive an education.

loans.use: to purchase an increased amount of sugar cane, which will aid her in improving her overall sales.

loans.name: Archelie

texts.en: Archelie is a merchant from Panglao, Bohol. She is a married woman and has run a fashion accessories shop for more than two years now. Her husband works as a driver. Archelie is asking for a loan to buy more shells for her handicraft business. With this loan, she will be able to create more accessories from shells. In the future, Archelie has hopes of making her business a success and sustainable. Moreover, she wants to save money for the future schooling of her young son.

loans.use: to buy more shells for her handicraft business.

loans.name: Gela

texts.en:
Gela is 40 years old. He lives in the Gardabani District with his wife, sister, retired mother, and two children (three and four years old). Gela requested a loan from local financial institutions several times for his family's business start-up, but without any success. His loan request was rejected each time, because of their low income and poor living conditions. 

The main source of the income for the family is from agricultural activities. They have two milk cows. The cows are milked every day and family makes dairy products, which are sold locally at the markets. Gela’s sister is working at the local shop as a seller and gets a small monthly salary. Additional family income is from Gela’s mother’s monthly pension.  

Gela requested a loan from Credo to start-up the family business. Gela has now been approved for a loan within the framework of the new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisages provision of business start-up and re-startup credits with soft conditions to rural poor people, who do not have access to credit products. These rural poor people are regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of their low income. 

With his credit, Gela will purchase chicks. He already has cages ready and will raise them. After the chicks are grown they will be sold at the local markets, and Gela will earn a good profit. He will reinvest part of the profit in the same business, in order to develop their poultry, and he will use another part for the family's well-being. The new business initiative, financed with the Kiva Start-up loan, will significantly improve the living conditions of the family.

loans.use: to purchase chicks

loans.name: Charlotte

texts.en:
Charlotte is married and has two children. She has received some schooling, until the end of junior high school. Currently, Charlotte sells ice creams and cocoa drinks in Hotopo (near Takoradi). She has been involved in this business activity for about four years now. Her husband is in a construction business.  Charlotte's income goes towards helping her husband pay for the family's general living expenses.

Charlotte will use the loan to increase her existing ice cream and cocoa drink capacity, by buying more inventory to sell. With the new profits from her expanded enterprise, Charlotte plans to develop her business further, by venturing into newer markets.

loans.use: to increase her existing ice cream and cocoa drink capacity.

loans.name: Wilma

texts.en: Wilma is a 40-year-old, married woman from Loon, Bohol. She has four children. Wilma runs a sari-sari (variety store) business, selling various goods and items to the people in her community. Wilma is asking for a loan to buy additional stock to sell, like canned goods, noodles, soda and beverages, soap and toiletries, and others. Through this loan, she will be able to improve her stock and attract more buyers, which will enable her to sell more and increase her profit.

loans.use: to buy additional stock to sell, like canned goods, noodles, soda and beverages, soap and toiletries.

loans.name: Colletar

texts.en:
Colletar is taking out another Kiva loan to improve her family’s living standards. The previous loan had a great impact on her business, as she was able to double her monthly profits. 

With the loan, Colletar wants to purchase chemicals, weaves, body lotions, bangles and necklaces for her clients. 

She is grateful for the opportunity given by Yehu Microfinance and Kiva lenders to access loans.

loans.use: to purchase chemicals, weaves, body lotions, bangles and necklaces for her clients.

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en: Although she grew up in difficult circumstances, Lucy is an entrepreneur. She specializes in selling provisions in Assiekie (which is near Cape Coast). She has been involved in this enterprise for 3 years.  Lucy is single without any children. The proceeds from her business normally go towards helping her support herself and her extended family. Lucy wants to use her loan to increase her current inventory levels, hence allowing her to sell greater quantities of provisions. In the long term, Lucy plans to reinvest future profits into her business, thus helping her expand and meet the needs of rising customer demands.

loans.use: to increase her current inventory levels, hence allowing her to sell greater quantities of provisions.

loans.name: Harusi

texts.en: Harusi is a married woman with five children, one of whom attends school. She lives at a rental house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and rental bills. For over ten years, she has operated a furniture shop business, where she sells furniture to her local neighbors. She faces a major challenge of the unavailability of timber for her business. She dreams of establishing a bigger shop in the future. With the KES 50,000 loan, she wants to purchase timber for her furniture shop business. Harusi decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase timber for her furniture shop business

loans.name: Esperanca

texts.en: Esperanca is taking a loan of $1000.00 to improve her business. She is running a kiosk that helps her to generate income for her family. She will use the loan to buy stocks for her store such as slippers, cigarettes, soft drinks and biscuits. She opened her kiosk in 2008 with her own working capital of $400.00. Esperanca is a hardworking woman and she hopes to run a bigger business in the future.

loans.use: to buy slippers, cigarettes, soft drinks and biscuits for sale

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en: This is Evelyn, 52, a resident of Silang, Cavite, the Philippines. She is married to Jose, a factory worker and they have children. She and her husband are working to provide income for their everyday expenses. Evelyn operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is a retail store that sells inexpensive items, often with a single price for all items in the store. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php 5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by pieces. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php500 in sales every day. She is requesting a Php 12,000 loan to help her continue this business. She will use the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. Evelyn hopes that her business will continue to expand and dreams to have a better living. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God she studies. All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business.

loans.name: Chinbaatar

texts.en: Mr. Chinbaatar, 47 years old, lives with his wife and two children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. The family resides in their own house on fenced land. He has been rendering transportation services to local people using his own truck. He usually finds his customers at outdoor markets. His wife works as a waitress at a university. The house the family lives in has deteriorated over the years and needs some urgent repairs. So he is requesting a loan of 6000000 MNT to purchase building and insulation materials such as bricks, planks, fiberglass and foam. Using these materials, he will repair and insulate his house, thus enabling his family to live in a comfortable and warm place. More importantly, the family will begin to burn less coal, emit less coal smoke and contribute to the efforts against air pollution. The borrower is a very hardworking individual who strives for a better future.

loans.use: to purchase building and insulation materials

loans.name: Douglas

texts.en: Douglas is a 27-year-old industrious man, married to Racheal and is a father of a seven year old daughter. He operates a grocery stall in Narok market and learnt about KADET LTD from some women in the market who are already registered members. He normally sells tomatoes that earns him a monthly income of KES. 9,000. He wants this first loan of KES 20,000 to buy more stock of tomatoes. He plans to use the proceeds to plow back into his business. His dream is to own a pickup truck to ease transportation of the produce.

loans.use: to buy more stock of tomatoes

loans.name: Riziki

texts.en: Riziki is a married woman with two children, one of whom attends school. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense are household consumables. For over three years, she has operated a cosmetic shop business, where she sells in a shop to her neighbors and passers-by. She faces the challenge of theft because of the low security in her place of operation. She dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future. With the Kshs 25,000 loan, she wants to purchase cosmetic products for her shop. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase cosmetic products for her shop.

loans.name: Sandy

texts.en:
This is Sandy. He previously accessed an 15,000 PHP loan that he used to purchase quantities of raw materials like fabric, thread and other materials needed in his business. His earnings were a big help for the education of his children as well as in their personal, household and business expenditures. He would like to apply for another 15,000 PHP loan to buy additional supplies of raw materials like thread, fabric and other things needed in his tailoring business. The profits from his business will definitely help him to sustain his daily needs and children’s education. He looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in his heart. Sandy hopes that his business will continue to grow. He meets up with his co-fellowship members to share stories of his work every week where he finds strength and inspiration from the Word of God he studies. 
* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for raw materials like thread, fabric and other things needed in his tailoring business.

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en: Eunice is taking out another Kiva loan to expand her existing cosmetic business. With the loan, she wants to purchase bangles, body lotions, weaves and necklaces. She is grateful for the opportunity given by Yehu Microfinance and Kiva lenders to access loans.

loans.use: to purchase bangles, body lotions, weaves and necklaces.

loans.name: Rasim

texts.en:
Rasim is 40 years old and has a family -- two sons and a wife.  He is involved in business, buying small calves, fattening them, and then selling the meat. He has been doing this business for 15 years and is very experienced. This is the only source of income for his family. He works very hard to give a good education to his sons.

Rasim sells meat in the central bazaar, in his shop. In Azerbaijan, people consume meat a lot, because many of the local meals are made primarily of beef. This is true especially on holidays, when people make traditional meals like kebobs, dolma, and pilaf, and they purchase more meat.

Rasim has taken a loan from Aqroinvest four times before, and this is his fifth loan. He has a good client history. This time, he requires a loan of 2,000 AZN. He will use it to buy four calves, to sell the meat in the upcoming summer. He expects that restaurants will buy more beef then, due to an increase in kebob sales that is typical in summer, in Azerbaijan.

loans.use: to buy four calves, to meet the increased demand for meat that comes in summer, in Azerbaijan

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice operates a cafe business, selling to her local residents. She appreciates the previous Kiva loan that helped her to facilitate her business, although she faces a major challenge of seasonality, especially during the rainy season when it becomes hard for her to operate her business. Her goal is to establish a restaurant business in the future.

With the 10,000 Kenyan shillings, she wants to purchase cooking utensils for her business. She decided to join Yehu because it supports small businesses.

loans.use: to purchase tea leaves, sugar, wheat flour, maize flour and cooking utensils for her business.

loans.name: Alice

texts.en: Alice is a 59-year-old hardworking widowed lady, and a mother of four. She operates a grocery stall in Narok, which earns her a monthly income of KES 30,000. She learnt about KADET LTD from other women in the market who have already been funded by KADET LTD. She is requesting her first loan of KES 30,000 from KADET LTD, which will facilitate the purchase of a variety of vegetables (cabbages, potatoes, onions and green peppers) as well as transportation of the same to her stall in the market. She will use the increased proceeds to pay for her children's school fees. Her hope is to own some rental houses.

loans.use: to purchase of a variety of vegetables as well as transport to her grocery stall

loans.name: Jecinta

texts.en: Jecinta is 45 years old, married and the mother of three children. She earns a living by raising and selling goats in Mpeketoni, Lamu, where she makes about KES.12,000 a month. Jecinta was introduced to KADET LTD. by one of our credit offices, and she has applied for a loan of KES. 30,000 to buy additional goats to fatten and sell later for a profit. She will use the profits she expects to earn to pay for her children's school fees. Jecinta intends to continue growing her business and hopes one day to engage in mixed farming.

loans.use: to buy additional goats to fatten and sell.

loans.name: Freydell Massiel

texts.es:
Freydell, habita en la ciudad de Estelí tiene negocio de costura lo cual lo tiene desde hace 5 años este es su segundo crédito con nosotros. Su crédito anterior lo utilizo para terminar de comprar una maquina overlop y compra de telas su crédito actual lo está solicitando para la compra de hilos, telas, agujas y terminar de comprar una maquina industrial ya que sus sueños son llegar a tener su propia marca de ropa y tener una empresa industrializada.
Ella dice que este segundo crédito la ayudara de mucho ya que va a poder ampliar el negocio así como la producción.
texts.en:
Freydell lives in the city of Estelí. For the past 5 years she has had a tailoring business. This is her second kiva loan. She used her previous loan to finish buying an overlock sewing machine as well as fabric. 

The loan that she is presently requesting is to purchase thread, fabric, needles and to finish buying an industrial sewing machine. 

Her dream is to have her own brand of clothing and to have an industrialized company. She says that this second loan will be a lot of help because she will be able to expand her business as well as her production.

loans.use: to purchase thread, fabric, needles etc.

loans.name: Halima

texts.en: Halima is a 42-year-old active lady. She has been stitching clothes for many years. She stitches for the people of her community and uses the income to support her entire family. However, due to lack of availability of funds, she is unable to meet with the daily demands of her customers. For this reason, she has requested a loan of Rs 30,000 from the Kashf Foundation. She intends to use this loan amount to buy more spools of threads in different colors with packs of laces, zippers and buttons to create a means of increasing revenues, so she may able to generate a healthier source of income. She is in her 8th loan cycle and is thankful to Kashf for its tremendous support.

loans.use: to buy more spools of threads in different colors with packs of laces, zippers and buttons.

loans.name: Rozinga

texts.en:
Rozinga is 40 years old, married, and a father of four children. For the last three years, he has earned a living by operating a metal shop, where he makes metal products such as gates, window frames, and so on, in Malindi. He earns a monthly income of about KES 10,200 from the business. 

Rozinga was introduced to KADET LTD by a credit officer. Now, he is applying for his second loan, in the amount of KES 30,000. He will use the loan to buy a welding machine that he needs for his work. He will use the profits made possible by this loan to pay school fees for his children, and to continue expanding the business. His goal for the future is to continue growing the business, so that he may uplift his family's financial stability

loans.use: to buy a welding machine

loans.name: Ana Griselda

texts.es: La Sra.  Ana Griselda de  44 años  es madre soltera  tiene  dos hijos  Ana de 10 años y Julio de 17 que actualmente estan estudiando ,   tiene 6 años con su  negocio  una   Estética, que  con su esfuerzo,  dedicacion y el amor que les tiene a sus hijos a podido salir adelante  con su  estetica ,   el dia de hoy esta solicitando el credito  para poder comprar productos  como tintes, Decolorantes, Peróxidos  y también   nos comenta que  requieren de otra clase de equipo para la realización de todo tipo de trabajos  ya que sus  clientes le piden trabajos especiales y en ocasiones no cuenta  con la  herramienta  necesaria  para llevarlos  acabo, Esto l e permitirá  hacer crecer su  negocio y dar un mejor servicio a sus clientes.
texts.en: Ana Griselda is 44 years old.  She is a single mother to two children - ten-year old Ana and 17-year-old Julio, who are both studying.  Ana Griselda has had her beauty salon for six years and with her effort, dedication and the love she has for her children, she has been able to prosper.  She is now applying for a loan to buy products such as dyes, bleaching agents and peroxide.  She also tells us that needs new equipment in order to offer all types of services.  Ana's customers sometimes request work that she does not have the necessary tools to do.  This loan will allow Ana to expand her business and offer better service to her customers.

loans.use: to buy dyes, bleaching agents, peroxide and more.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Sonia

texts.en:
This is Sonia, 63, a resident of Silang, Cavite, in the Philippines. She is married to Fortunato, a sewer, and they have children. Together with her husband, Sonia manages the household while operating her buy-and-sell business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for the family's everyday expenses.
                             
Sonia's business is to buy and sell bags. She is also a sewer. She makes curtains, bed sheets, blankets and other goods for the home, as well as seasonal clothing, like uniforms and such, all year round. She does repairs and alterations as well.  Her regular customers are her neighbors and members of the local community. She earns a minimum of 500 Philippine pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help her continue operating her business, she is requesting a loan of 18,000 PHP. She will use the loan to buy quantities and varieties of bags and materials for her tailoring business. 

Sonia hopes that her business will continue to grow and she dreams of a good life. She meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her life and business every week and, in the process, she grows in her relationship with God.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet weekly. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for bags needed in her business.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Due to difficult circumstances, Elizabeth did not have access to any formal education while growing up, yet this has not stopped her from achieving her dream of becoming an entrepreneur. For the last three years, she has earned a living by selling cooking oil in the town of Whindo. She is married and the mother of six children. Elizabeth uses all of her income to feed and provide for her family, and will use this loan to improve her sales by buying an increased amount of cooking oil. She wants to use the profits she makes from her business to ensure that all of her children are able to receive an education.

loans.use: to buy cooking oil to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is a married woman with four children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees. 

For the past year, she has operated a food kiosk business; selling the household consumables of wheat flour, maize flour and sugar. She sells at the market to her local neighbours. 

Mary faces a major challenge of high transportation costs in her place of operation. 

With the Kshs 10,000, she wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, rice, sugar and tea leaves. 

She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, rice, sugar and tea leaves.

loans.name: Halima

texts.en:
Halima is 31 years old, married, and a mother of three children. For the last three years, she has earned a living by selling fruits and vegetables from her food kiosk in Malindi. She earns a monthly income of about KES 9,000 from the business. 

Halima was introduced to KADET LTD by a credit officer, and she is applying for her first loan of KES 30,000. She will use the loan to buy more stock of tomatoes, pineapples, oranges and onions, to sell to her customers. 

She will use the profits to pay school fees for her children and to continue expanding the business. Her goal for the future is to continue growing the business, so that she may uplift her family's financial stability.

loans.use: to buy more stock of tomatoes, pineapples, oranges and onions, to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Kuña Aty Group

texts.es:
El grupo llamado Kuña Aty está en su ciclo número 3 del programa de comité de mujeres, donde todas están poniendo su mayoes esfuerzo por salir adelante, ayudar a sus familias y sus hijos.
Una de las integrantes es la Sra. Lorens quien comenta que entre el trabajo que ella hace es la compra y venta de pescado y queso, venta de sabana y artículos de primera necesidad. Lo que mas se destaca es el esfuerzo de esta señora por salir adelante y crecer, y poder ayudar a su familia.
La Sra. Lorens  solicita de este crédito para la compra de pescados, quesos y productos de primera necesidad como ser Jabon, Azúcar,y Harina, lo que le ayudará a tener a concretar su plan de negocio, el cual le ayudará a mejorar sus ingresos.
texts.en:
This group, called "Kuña Aty", is on its third loan cycle as part of the women's committee programme, where all the women put in the greatest possible effort in order to prosper and to help their families and children.

One of the group's members is Lorens who tells us that some of the work she does includes buying and selling fish and cheese, selling bed sheets and selling staple goods.  One characteristic that stands out in Lorens is the effort that she puts in to prosper and grow in order to help her family.

Lorens is applying for this loan in order to buy fish, cheese and staple goods, such as soap, sugar and flour.  This loan will help Lorens to realise her business plan, which will allow her to improve her income.

loans.use: to buy fish, cheese and staple goods.

loans.name: Leonora

texts.en:
Leonora is a 40-year-old, married woman and a mother of six children. She lives in Loon, Bohol. Leonora has been engaged in a hog-raising business for more than five years. Leonora works hard, in order to support her husband in meeting the needs of their family, especially the schooling of their children.

Leonora is asking for a loan to buy more pigs, food supplements and feed. Through this loan, she will be able to improve her business and augment her income.

loans.use: to buy more pigs, and food supplements, and feed

loans.name: Karine

texts.en:
Karine is a 53 year old shining lady. She lives with her son in Sevan city. Karine’s husband works abroad. He works in Russia to help meet his family's needs in Armenia. 
Karine graduated from Sevan Industrial College and used to work as a nurse in Sevan’s kindergarten schools. As her salary was too low, Karine decided to run her own business and after the Soviet Union collapse, Karine engaged in clothing trading. Now Karine is a good merchandiser with extensive work experience.
Once a month she buys clothes for women and children from Yerevan wholesale markets and from Georgia and sells them in her rented stall at the Sevan clothing market.  From time to time her son helps her in trading but he also works as a guard at a hospital. 
Karine says that she is a very happy woman because she founded her business and is able to care for her family herself. 
Karine asks from Kiva lenders a 500,000 Armenian dram loan to buy spring and summer clothes to resell in her stall.

loans.use: To buy spring and summer clothes to resell in her stall

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce is a married woman. She owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

She operates a food stall business, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. She faces the challenge of stiff competition from other food stall operators. 

With the Kshs 40,000, that she is requesting she wants to pay school fees for her children who attend school. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to pay school fees for her children who attend school.

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en:
Catherine is 36 year old and the sole proprietor of a ladies’ wear shop in Magongo, Mombasa. She is also a married mother who supports a family of three. Her spouse provides additional income. 

Catherine has been in this business for the last three-and-a-half years and has done great. This marks her third loan from the Kenya Agency for Development of Enterprise and Technology, used to finance her business. With this loan, she will purchase new ladies’ clothes for her shop and use the anticipated profits to expand her business. 

She hopes to continue working with KADET for financing until she owns a boutique.

loans.use: to purchase new ladies' clothes for her shop

loans.name: Oliva

texts.en: Oliva is a 30-year-old married woman with 4 children living in Bundibugyo, Uganda. Three years ago she decided to venture into fish sales in order to raise money for her family’s basic needs. She desires to educate her children up to the university level while her business plan is to buy a refrigerated van, as the fish can go bad quickly due to poor preservation methods. Oliva intends to use the loan to buy fish to sell.

loans.use: to buy fish to sell.

loans.name: Efua

texts.en:
Efua grew up in poverty and without an education, yet this has not stopped her from fulfilling her dream of achieving a better life for herself and her family. Currently, Efua is an entrepreneur. She sells provisions in Whindo (near Takoradi). Her business enterprise has grown substantially since she began, three years ago. She uses the income from her business to help her husband raise their six children 

Efua has identified that there is growing demand among consumers for her products. Nevertheless, she is unable to meet their needs due to limited inventory capacity. Thus, she aims to use her loan to purchase more provisions to sell. With the new profits from her expanded business, Efua wants to buck the trend, by ensuring that all her children will be given the opportunity to further distance their family from poverty.

loans.use: to purchase more provisions to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase sheep to sell

loans.name: Faustina's Group

texts.en:
43-year-old Faustina is the leader of this group. The rest are Hanah and Patrick. She has no children, and she is married. She makes a living by selling provisions (e.g., milk, Milo, sugar, rice, bread) in a small store near her community.

She is requesting a loan of GHS 2,000. She will use her part of the group's loan to buy more provisions, in order to satisfy the demand from her customers. They buy from her, because she sells affordable items. Her dream is to be able to build her own house, on a small plot of land she inherited from her parents. She hopes that, with your help, she will be able to get ahead in her business.

The group members need a total amount of GHS 4,600, to buy enough and satisfy their customers.

loans.use: to buy more provisions, in order to satisfy the demand from her customers.

loans.name: Ndable

texts.en: Ndable is widow and the mother of two children. Even though she did not receive any formal education, she is a successful businesswoman who sells a variety of African dishes at a "chop bar" in the town of Whindo. She has been in this business for about five years and, as sole breadwinner for her family, uses her income to provide for her children. Ndable is requesting this loan to buy ingredients she needs to prepare the dishes she sells. She believes that this loan will help her increase her sales and expand her business. In the future, she plans to offer a wider range of food items, and thereby adapt to changing customer preferences.

loans.use: to buy ingredients to prepare food to sell.

loans.name: Nodar

texts.en:
Nodar is 58 years old. He lives in Gardabani District with his 52-year-old wife and two children (28 and 30 years old). 

Nodar has requested a loan from the local financial institutions several times for a family business start-up, but without any success. His loan request has been rejected every time, because of low income and the family’s poor living conditions. 

The main source of income for the family is from agricultural activities. They have a milk cow. The cow is milked every day and the family makes dairy products, which are sold locally at the markets. Nodar’s daughter is working at the local shop as a seller and gets a small monthly salary. 

Nodar requested a loan from Credo to start-up a family business. Nodar has now been approved for a loan within the framework of the new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisages provision for business start-ups and re-startup credits with soft conditions for rural poor people, who do not have access to credit products. These rural poor people are regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of their low income. 

With his credit, Nodar will purchase chicks and a calf. He already has the cages ready, where he will raise the chicks. After the chicks and calf are grown they will be sold at the local markets and Nodar will earn a good profit. He will reinvest part of the profit in the same business, in order to develop their agricultural business and use another part to provide better living conditions for the family.

loans.use: To purchase chicks and a calf

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is a married mother. She lives in a rental house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is her rental bills.

For over one year, she has operated a vegetable stall business, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. She faces the challenge of the high cost of transportation in her business. She dreams of establishing a café in the future. 

With the 40,000 KES, she wants to purchase green vegetables, tomatoes, potatoes and onions. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase green vegetables, tomatoes, potatoes and onions for her vegetable stall.

loans.name: Francis

texts.en:
Francis is 71 years old, married and a father of three children. For the last seven years, he has earned a living by selling farm produce in Mpeketoni, Lamu. He earns a monthly profit of KES. 8,000.
Francis was introduced to KADET LTD by a credit officer, and is applying for his fourth loan of KES 20,000, to buy seeds, some fertilizer and other farm inputs needed for his business. He will use the profits made possible by this loan to pay school fees for one of his grandchildren as well as expand his farming activities.
His goal for the future is to venture into mixed farming with a view of increasing his income so as to help improve his family's living standards.

loans.use: to buy seeds, some fertilizer and other farm inputs needed for farming.

loans.name: Augustina

texts.en: After graduating junior high school, Augustina decided to set up her own dress making business in Whindo, near Takoradi. With over 10 years of experience, she is currently looking to expand her enterprise further. Unfortunately, she is limited due to a lack of funding. As a result, this loan will be used to help her by purchase an additional sewing machine to make her work easier. She aims to use the profits from her business to help support her husband with the upkeep of their house whilst ensuring that their 2 children are able to experience a better life.

loans.use: to purchase an additional sewing machine.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is married to a contractor. She has 5 children. She uses her income to help her husband pay the household expenses as well as save for a rainy day. As a junior-high school graduate, Mary currently sells vegetables, fish, and other food items in Whindo (near Takoradi). With over 3 years of experience in this trade, Mary sees an opportunity to expand her enterprise further. Nevertheless, she does not have the working capital necessary to increase her quantity of stock. Thus her loan will be used to buy more items, indirectly helping her boost her overall sales.

loans.use: to buy more vegetables, fish and food items, indirectly helping her boost her overall sales.

loans.name: Petronila

texts.en:
Petronila is a married woman with three school-aged children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are school fees and food. 

For the past one year, she has operated a food kiosk business, selling household consumables of wheat flour, maize flour and sugar. She sells at the market to her local neighbors. Petronila faces a major challenge of the high cost of transportation in her place of operation. 

With the Kshs 10,000 she wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, rice, sugar and tea leaves. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, rice, sugar and tea leaves.

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Lucy is a 42-year-old lady, married to David and a mother of seven children. 

She does horticultural farming and has been in the business for five years now. She gets a monthly income of 25,000 KES. 

This will be Lucy's seventh loan with KADET LTD. She plans to use the entire loan to purchase seeds and fertilizer. 

In the future, she wants to become a successful business lady.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, seeds, etc

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Even though Elizabeth  grew up in poverty without an education, this has not stopped her from fulfilling her dream of achieving a better life for her and her family. Currently, Elizabeth is an entrepreneur.  She sells bread eggs and vegetables in Whindo (near Takoradi). Her business enterprise has grown substantially since she began 2 years ago. 

She uses the income from her business to help her husband raise their 4 children.  Elizabeth has identified that there are growing demands among consumers for her products. She is unable to meet their needs due to limited inventory capacity. Thus she aims to use her loan to purchase more bread, eggs and vegetables  to sell. With the new profits from her expanded business, Elizabeth  wants to buck the trend by ensuring that all her children will be given the opportunity to further distance their family from poverty.

loans.use: to purchase more bread, eggs and vegetables  to sell.

loans.name: Dúo Rositas De San Mateo Group

texts.es:
dúo Rositas de San Mateo
Este dúo está conformado por doña María Salome, ella tiene 55 años de edad, tiene un hijo varón que estudia en su nivel básico, doña Mari como la conocen sus clientes se dedica a la venta de comida  variada tales como pepián, hilachas, revolcado, frijoles blancos con carne de marrano etc. y venta de tortillas en su local ubicado en frente del parque de su aldea San Mateo Milpas Altas, ella está solicitando el crédito para la compra de mercaderia en productos comestibles para la elaboracion de comidas y tambien para la compra de material para la elaboracion de una plancha para cosinar sus alimentos ya que no cuenta con uno y su deseo es mejorar el servicio de sus clientes y tambin para la compra de leña así como inversión de carnes, verduras y arroz que es lo que comúnmente usa día a día, espera que ustedes le puedan ayudar con el credito solicitado.
texts.en: This is the group "Duo Rositas de San Mateo."  One of the members is Maria Salome, 55, who has a son who attends school.  The other is Mari, as she is known by her customers, who has a business selling a variety of food including: stew, shredded beef, curried pork stew, white beans with pork, other dishes, and tortillas.  Her business is located at the front of a park in the town of San Mateo Milpas Altas.  She is requesting a loan to buy ingredients to make her dishes, and also to buy material to make a griddle to cook her food on, because she doesn't have one and she wants to improve her customer service.  She also wants to buy firewood and to invest in meats, vegetables, and rice, which are the products that she uses daily.  She hopes that you can help her with the loan that she is requesting.

loans.use: to buy ingredients to make food, and to purchase material to make a griddle to cook with

loans.name: Epemia

texts.en:
Epemia is 35 years old. She lives in the Sagarejo District with her husband, daughter and parents-in-law, who are provided with a retirement pension. Epemia has requested a loan from her local financial institutions several times to start up a family business without any success. Her loan requests were rejected each time because of her low income and the family’s poor living conditions. 

The family is involved in the poultry business. They have hens and sell eggs at the local markets. Besides, Epemia’s daughter is a tailor and gets orders to sew clothing. It is hardly enough to provide food for the family. According to Credo's estimations, the family belongs in the subsistence poor category. 

Epemia requested this loan from Credo to start up a family business. She has been approved for a loan within the framework of the new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisages the provision of business start-up and re-startup credits with soft conditions to rural poor people who do not have access to credit products. These rural poor people are regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of their low income. With her credit, Epemia will begin a clothing business. She plans to purchase clothing at wholesale prices and then resell the clothes at a higher price. This will increase her family's income. This new business initiative, financed with this Kiva start-up loan, will significantly improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: to begin a clothing business.

loans.name: Khatuni

texts.en:
Khatuni is 40 years old and lives in Tbilisi, the capital of Georgia, with her husband and two children. She has requested a loan for a start-up business from local financial institutions several times but without any success. Her request was rejected because of her family's low income and poor living conditions. Khatuni’s husband works as an artisan for a private company and earns a small monthly income while she works in a supermarket. These are the only sources of income for the family, which means they can scarcely buy enough food to eat. According to Kiva partner Credo, the family belongs to the subsistence poor category. 

Khatuni has requested loan to start-up a family business under a new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo which provides start-up money to the rural poor. With his loan, she will buy perfume at wholesale prices and then resell it for a higher price in the supermarket where she works. This will increase the income of the family and significantly improve its living conditions.

loans.use: to buy perfume to resell.

loans.name: Lesbia Escorcia

texts.es: Doña Lesbia, es soltera sus hijos son casados e independientes, se dedica a la venta de ropa como cobertores y sabanas de segunda mano de manera ambulante, a diario sale todas las mañanas con la esperanza de poder vender algo para mantener sus gatos básicos del hogar como la alimentación, pagos de recibos de agua, luz entre otros que son de primera necesidad. En la actualidad tiene muy pocos productos, es por eso que solicita en este primer crédito con Afodenic para comprar más ropa de paca.
texts.en:
Lesbia is single. Her children are married and independent. She sells second-hand clothes, quilts and sheets as a mobile vendor. She leaves her house every morning with the hope of making some sales in order to cover her basic household expenses, such as food, and water and electricity bills, as well as other essential items. 

At present she has very few products. For this reason, she is requesting her first loan with Afodenic, so that she can buy more bundles of used clothes.

loans.use: to buy bundles of used clothes

loans.name: Robinah

texts.en:
Robinah is married with three children, and all of her children are in school. She doesn’t take care of additional family members. She has a restaurant and has been in business for five moths now. She has applied for a loan of Ugandan shillings from MCDTSD+SACCO to buy more bunches of green bananas, beef, restaurant chairs, chickens and serving utensils.   

Robinah works at the market seven days a week. Her major business challenges include a lack of enough customers, seasonality and defaulters. She resides in her own house, and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees, paying utility bills and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of green bananas, restaurant chairs, chickens and serving utensils.

loans.name: Florence

texts.en: Florence  is widowed with four children, two of whom go to school. She earns a living by selling African clothing (known as bitenge). She has applied for a loan for 400,000 Uganda shillings from MCDT SACCO to buy more clothing to sell. Florence generates additional income on the side by renting rooms. She works in a shop six days a week and sells on retail basis only. Her major business challenges include seasonality and people who default on loans. She wants to start a new business selling clothing imported from the Democratic Republic of Congo. She lives in her own house but her family has no  access to electricity and piped-in water. Her largest monthly expenses include school fees and food.

loans.use: to buy more clothing to sell.

loans.name: Josphine

texts.en:
Josphine is coming again to Yehu Microfinance for another Kiva loan of KES 10,000. With the loan, she plans to expand her food market business. 

Josphine wants to purchase bags of vegetables, onions, tomatoes, and bananas to sell. 

She is grateful for Yehu and Kiva lenders for the opportunity given to improve her family living standards.

loans.use: to purchase bags of vegetables, onions, tomatoes, and bananas to sell.

loans.name: Tsira

texts.en:
Tsira is 34 years old; she lives in Kondoli village, Telavi District with her 43-year-old husband David, and 12- old-daughter, Ana. 

Tsira requested a loan from local financial institutions several times for a family business start-up, without success. Her loan request was rejected each time, due to of income and family’s poor living conditions. 

The family owns a small plot of land where maize, haricots, and tomatoes are grown. The harvested products are sold locally at the markets. Tsira’s husband is an artisan, and he works at the local factory for a small monthly salary.

Tsira has requested a loan from Credo to do a start-up family business. Tsira has now been approved for a loan within the framework of the the new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisages provision of business start-up and re-startup credits with soft conditions to rural poor people, who do not have access to credit products. These rural poor people are regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of their low income. 

With her credit, Tsira will purchase eggs and chicken feed to develop a poultry business. She will incubate the eggs, feed the chicks, and sell them at the local markets. This will help Tsira to earn a good profit. She will reinvest part of the profit in the same field to expand her business. Another part she will use to install a gas system in her house. This will significantly improve the family's living conditions.

loans.use: To purchase eggs and chicken feed.

loans.name: Francis

texts.en:
Francis is 41 years old, married and the father of three children. For the past four years, he has earned a living by repairing motorcycles in Malindi. He earns a monthly profit of about KES 10,000 from the business. 

Francis was introduced to KADET LTD by our credit officer, and is applying for his second loan of KES 22,000 to buy additional tools such as screw drivers, chains, tires, lubricants and so on for the smooth running of his business. 

He will use the profits made possible by this loan to pay school fees for his children, as well as to continue expanding the business. 

His goal for the future is to continue growing the businesses so that he may improve his financial stability.

loans.use: to buy additional tools such as screw drivers, chains, tires, and lubricants.

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan is a fifty-four year old woman, and she is married to Samuel and has one child. She owns a dairy farm in Kangemi. Susan has been in this business for fourteen years now and has a monthly income of sixteen thousand shillings. 

This will be her fourth loan with KADET LTD, and she plans on using the entire loan to purchase a dairy cow and dairy feed. In the future, she plans to buy more dairy cows.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow and dairy feed.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is a mother of three children, two of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is household consumables. 

For over one year, she has operated a fruit and vegetable stall, selling at the the market to her town dwellers and local residents. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in fruits. She dreams of establishing a grocery business in the future. 

With the 10,000 KES, she wants to purchase bags of green vegetables, onions, tomatoes, mangoes and oranges. She decided to join Yehu because of the availability of a variety of loan products.

loans.use: to purchase bags of green vegetables, onions, tomatoes, mangoes and oranges.

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en:
Eunice is a twenty-four year old woman. She is married to Kennedy and is a mother of two children. She sells clothing like skirts and blouses in Kangemi. She has been in this business for five years, and she earns a monthly income of fifty thousand shillings. 

This will be Eunice's first loan with KADET LTD, and she plans on using the entire loan to purchase more clothing to sell. She plans on using the profits to pay school fees and improve her business. In the future she wants to expand her business and be a prosperous business woman.

loans.use: To buy new clothing for her business

loans.name: Salome

texts.en:
Salome, a 36-year-old lady who is married to Benson and a mother of three children, sells security gadgets in Nairobi. In this business for nine years now, she earns a monthly income of 100,000 shillings.

This will be Salome's first loan with KADET LTD, with which she plans to buy more security gadgets for resale. In the future, she wants to educate her children to higher levels.

loans.use: To buy security gadgets to sell.

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine is married with one child, and her only child goes to school. She also takes care of additional family (her mummy and daddy). She has a business of making necklaces. She has applied for a loan from MCDTSACCO to buy more beads and polyethylene bags of bangles. She doesn’t have any other income-generating activity. She works from home seven days out of every week. Her major business challenges include seasonality and defaulters.   

She is aspiring of seeing her business grow big so that she employs some people to assist in making necklaces and also to become a wholesaler. She resides in her own house, and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses includes school fees for her child, medication and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more beads and polyethylene bags of bangles.

loans.name: Emma

texts.en: Emma is coming again to Yehu Microfinance for a new Kiva loan of 10,000 Kenyan shillings. With the loan, she plans to expand her business. She wants to purchase more tomatoes, cabbages, potatoes, cooking oil, charcoal and onions. In addition to this, she opperates a clothes-selling business as her other source of income. She is grateful for Yehu and Kiva lenders for the opportunity given to improve her family's living standards.

loans.use: to purchase more tomatoes, cabbages, potatoes, cooking oil, charcoal and onions.

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice has operated a kiosk business selling food at at an open air market to her local residents. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. She dreams of establishing a shop in the future.

With the Kshs 40,000 she wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, sugar and cooking oil. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business and she appreciates the previous Kiva loan that helped her to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of vegetables, sugar, tea leaves, maize flour and cooking oil.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase cloth in bulk, clothing decorations and supplies, paints and brushes.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more rice, cassava, plantains and vegetables to sell to customers.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth sells different kinds of  soap at Jukwa near Abura in Ghana which she has done for 14 years now. She is married and has 2 children.  Elizabeth uses her income to help her husband to pay their household bills.  Elizabeth will use her loan to purchase soap to sell. With the new profit she will expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase soap to sell.

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith is a married woman. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is household items. 

She has operated an open-air food selling business, selling from home to local residents. She faces a major challenge of seasonality, especially during the rainy season when it becomes hard for her to operate her business. Her goal is to establish a restaurant business in the future. 

With the 20,000 Kenyan shillings, she wants to purchase cooking utensils, rice and wheat flour for her business. She decided to join Yehu because it supports small businesses.

loans.use: to purchase cooking utensils, rice and wheat flour for her business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a heater, dividing wall, shutters, equipment, food materials and supplies.

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en: Due to difficult circumstances Cecilia  did not have access to any form of formal education. This has not stopped her from achieving her dream of becoming an entrepreneur. Currently, Cecilia sells footwear and clothing  in Whindo (near Takoradi) in Ghana. She has been doing so for about 2 years. She is married to a driver, and together they have 3 children.  Cecilia uses all her income to feed and provide for her family. Cecilia will use the loan to purchase an increased amount of footwear and clothing, which will aid her in improving her overall sales.  Cecilia wants to use the future profits from her expanded business to ensure that all her children are able to receive an education.

loans.use: to purchase an increased amount of footwear and clothing,

loans.name: Doris

texts.en: Although she grew up in difficult circumstances, Kwofie is an entrepreneur. She specializes in selling plastic bowls and cups in Whindo (near Takoradi) in Ghana. She has been involved in this enterprise for 2 years.  Doris is single without any children. The proceeds from her business normally go towards helping her support herself and her extended family.  Doris wants to use her loan to increase her current inventory levels allowing her to sell greater quantities of plastic bowls and cups. In the long term, Doris plans to reinvest future profits into her business, thus helping her expand and meet the needs of rising customer demands.

loans.use: increase her current inventory levels allowing her to sell greater quantities of plastic bowls and cups.

loans.name: Mary's Group

texts.en:
Cecilia is the leader of this group. The members are located in the city of Accra in Ghana. She lives with her husband in a rented room. She says that her most difficult challenge has been to improve her business, something she continues to work very hard at. In the meantime, she need an amount of GHS 1400 to be able to expand business by buying and selling more jewelry and bags.She has been running this business for 10 years now.

The group includes Janet, Mary and Mary and they need a total amount of GHS 4400 to be able to expand their businesses and serve customers better.

loans.use: To buy more jewelry and bags to sell to customers

loans.name: Ama

texts.en:
Although Ama grew up in poverty without an education, it has not stopped her from fulfilling her dream of achieving a better life for her and her family. Ama is an entrepreneur who operates a chop bar (where a variety of African dishes are sold) in Whindo, near Takoradi. Her business has grown substantially since she began it eight years ago, and she uses her income to help her husband raise their seven children.

Ama has identified growing demand among consumers for her product but is unable to meet their needs due to limited inventory capacity. She has therefore requested this loan to purchase more foodstuffs and other ingredients to prepare more of her dishes to sell. With the new profits from her expanded enterprise, Ama wants to ensure that all of her children will be given the opportunity to further distance themselves and their family from poverty.

loans.use: to purchase more foodstuffs and other ingredients to prepare more dishes to sell.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is married and the mother of two children. She attended primary school and today earns a living by running a grocery store in the town of Whindo. She has been in this line of work for four years while her husband works in construction. Her income goes towards helping her husband pay for the family's general expenses. She has requested a loan to buy more groceries to sell and plans to use the addition income she earns to venture into newer markets.

loans.use: to buy more groceries to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Hilda

texts.en:
Hilda is a business management student at the Maharishi Institute. Hilda is 23 years old and was asked the following questions by a staff member of the Institute:

What do you study at the Maharishi Institute and what classes do you enjoy most?
“I am studying towards a business degree, towards a Bachelor of Business Administration. I enjoy Physiology is Consciousness and am currently doing Organizational Management.”

What are your goals after graduation?
“After graduation, I want to be in the hospitality sector, as I have a passion for travel and tourism. I would like to live in the city of Gold, Johannesburg. I would like to tour my country and abroad.”

Tell us about your background?
“I was born in Pretoria, in Soshangure. I am the only child. I’m an orphan. I am single and do not have a child. My guardian is my grandmother.”

What do you do in your spare time?
“I like reading novels, Internet - finding/learning new things, playing brain games, listening to music, dancing, traveling to new places and meeting new people.”

How will the Kiva Loan change your life?
“The loan will help a lot, by helping me reduce the Maharishi Institute fees. The money will also help me with my monthly expenses, like paying for my accommodation. It will help my grandmother by supporting me with the stipend.”

loans.use: to pay for one year of tuition fees and living expenses at the Maharishi Institute.

loans.name: Diana

texts.en: Diana is married with 2 children. She has received some schooling through the end of junior high school. Currently, Diana sells groceries in Whindo (near Takoradi) in Ghana.  She has been involved in this industry for about 2 years. Her husband is in construction. Diana's  income goes towards helping her husband pay for the family's general expenses. Diana will use the loan to increase her existing stock. With the profit from her expanded enterprise, Diana plans to develop her business further by venturing into new markets.

loans.use: to increase her existing stock

loans.name: Theresah

texts.en: Although she has received no formal education, Theresa is an entrepreneur. She specializes in selling provisions in  Whindo (near Takoradi) in Ghana. She has been involved in this enterprise for 8 years. Theresa  is married and has 5 children. Her husband works as a farmer. The proceeds from her business normally go towards helping her husband cover the family’s general expenses and pay for their children’s school fees. Theresa  wants to use her loan to increase her current inventory levels allowing her to sell greater quantities of provisions.   In the long term, Theresa  plans to reinvest future profits into her business, thus helping her expand and meet the needs of rising customer demands.

loans.use: increase her current inventory levels allowing her to sell greater quantities of provisions.

loans.name: Abie

texts.en:
This is Abie who is 40 years old and is from Jui eastern area in Freetown. She is married with five children between the ages of twelve and twenty-one.

Abie runs a shoe business where she sells different types of rubber slippers. She has been running this business for ten years. She works 11 hours per day, six days a week. Her is husband is a driver, but at present, he doesn't have his own vehicle. So Abie takes the responsibility all by herself. She says that the main challenge for her business is a lack of sufficient capital to run her business.

Abie has requested a loan in order to buy more slippers along with a little retail business. The extra income from this loan will allow her to improve her status by allowing her to eat three meals every day and increasing her business. In the future, she plans to open a big shop. She appreciates your support.

loans.use: to buy more slippers along with a little retail business.

loans.name: Jariatu

texts.en:
Jariatu is in her early thirties and married with 2 children, ages 1 year and 10 years old. She runs a clothing business in the Jui Western area in Freetown.

She's been in this business for more than five years and sells used clothing within a busy market area.  She says that the main challenge to her business is price inflation.

She requested this loan through BRAC Sierra Leone to buy different types of clothing such as trousers. She says that the extra income from this loan will help her improve the life of her family and increase her business so it can create more sales for her. In the future, she would like to open a big shop. She is grateful for your support.

loans.use: to buy different types of used clothing such as trousers.

loans.name: Ama

texts.en:
Even though Ama grew up in poverty without an education, this has not stopped her from fulfilling her dream of achieving a better life for her and her family. Currently, Ama is an entrepreneur. She produces palm oil for sale  in Whindo (near Takoradi). Her business enterprise has grown substantially since she began 8 years ago. She uses the income from her business to help her husband raise their 4 children.  

Ama  has identified that there are growing demands among consumers for her product. However, she  is unable to meet their needs due to limited inventory capacity. Thus she aims to use her loan to purchase more palm fruit to produce her oil  to sell. With the new profits from her expanded business, Ama  wants to ensure that all her children will be given the opportunity to further distance their family from poverty.

loans.use: to purchase more palm fruit to produce her oil  to sell.

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah is married with 4 children. She received some schooling, up until the end of primary. Currently, Sarah  sells provisions in Whindo (near Takoradi). She has been involved in this industry for about  4 years now. Her husband works in construction.   

Sarah's income goes towards helping her husband pay for the family's general expenses. Sarah  will use the loan to increase her existing provisions'  capacity. With the new profits from her expanded enterprise, Sarah plans to develop her business further by venturing into newer markets.

loans.use: to increase her existing provisions' capacity.

loans.name: Tshepo

texts.en:
Tshepo is a business management student at the Maharishi Institute. Tshepo was asked the following questions by a staff member of the Institute:

What do you study at the Maharishi Institute and what classes do you enjoy most?
“Consciousness-based education. I enjoy my academic classes.”

What are your goals after graduation?
“Management, I hope. I want to start my own company and travel the world.”

Tell us about your background?
I was born and raised in Soweto. I have one younger sister. My mother passed away due to breast cancer; I live with my grandparents at the moment. I don’t have any children yet.”

What do you do in your spare time?
“I am an up-and-coming music producer and writer. I love reading books on spirituality and art.”

How will the Kiva loan change your life?
“I will feel more relaxed knowing that my studies are taken care of, and I will make sure that I have finished school.”

loans.use: to pay for one year of tuition fees and living expenses at the Maharishi Institute.

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Although she has received no prior formal education, Ruth is an entrepreneur. She specializes in selling clothing in Whindo (near Takoradi). She has been involved in this enterprise for two years. Ruth is married and has one child, and her husband works as a driver. The proceeds from her business normally go towards helping her husband cover the family’s general expenses and pay their children’s school fees.  

Ruth wants to use her loan to increase her current inventory levels, hence allowing her to sell greater quantities of clothing and dresses. For the long term, she plans to reinvest future profits into her business, thus helping her expand and meet the needs of rising customer demands.

loans.use: to increase her current inventory levels, hence allowing her to sell greater quantities of clothing and dresses.

loans.name: Kagiso

texts.en:
Kagiso is a business management student at the Maharishi Institute. Kagiso is 22 years old and was asked the following questions by a staff member of the Institute:

What do you study at the Maharishi Institute and what classes do you enjoy most?
“I am studying for a Bachelor of Business Administration (degree) and I enjoy business classes and consciousness classes most.”

What are your goals after graduation?
“I would like to manage a media company around Johannesburg or Pretoria after graduating.”

Tell us about your background?
“I was born in Pretoria, and I have two little sisters and one brother. I have a single parent and she is not working at the moment. We are only four at home. I am not married and I don’t have a child.”

What do you do in your spare time?
“In my spare time I like to produce music and read some books, magazines and newspapers or play some games sometimes.”

How will the Kiva loan change your life?
“If a Kiva loan approves me, I could at least afford to buy some food for every month using the money I receive from Kiva. My studies will be paid also, and my life will change. I will be offered a chance to study.”

loans.use: to pay for one year of tuition fees and living expenses at the Maharishi Institute.

loans.name: Alltane

texts.en: Alltane is 40 years old, married and has four children, one of whom is currently attending school. The family lives in a minority community in a small house that is in very poor condition. Alltane is a housewife and her husband works in construction. They started to add a room on to their house but can’t finish the work because of a lack of money. That is why she is requesting a loan to buy building materials, doors and windows to finish the renovation and give her children a pleasant place to study. She hopes in the future to provide better living conditions to her children. She and her family want to thank all Kiva lenders for their help!

loans.use: to buy building materials for a renovation.

loans.name: Esi

texts.en:
Esi is a small-scale ‘wakye’ seller (wakye is a traditional Ghanaian dish made primarily of beans, rice and colored leaves). She mostly sells her ‘wakye’ in Whindo (near Takoradi). She has had some form of formal education, as she is a middle-school form four graduate. She is married and has six children, and her husband is a farmer.  

Esi has been preparing and selling ‘wakye’ for close to six years. Her income is used to help her husband pay the utility bills and their children’s school fees. She plans on using her loan to purchase more rice and beans, thus allowing her to meet rising customers’ demands. She hopes to use the profits from her enterprise to fulfill her dream of mounting a ‘wakye’ stand, hence helping her sell from a fixed location in the future.

loans.use: to purchase more rice and beans for her 'wakye' business.

loans.name: María Romelia

texts.es: María Romelia de 46 años de edad, es una mujer luchadora y con ganas de emprender camino hacia el éxito. Cuenta que desde joven aprendió el oficio de la confección y lo ejerció durante varios años en diferentes empresas. Con el nacimiento de su tercer hijo se vio en la obligación de abandonar su trabajo y dedicarse a su cuidado. Hoy después de trece años de suspender la actividad, desea reiniciar nuevamente con el fin de mejorar la calidad de vida de su familia, por lo cual se encuentra solicitando un crédito para la compra de una máquina de coser con la que iniciará su proyecto de negocio. Sueña con la posibilidad de tener un gran taller en donde pueda convertirse en una fuente de empleo directo.
texts.en:
María Romelia is 46 years old. She is a determined woman with the will to undertake the path towards success. She says that when she was young she learned the dressmaking trade y she practiced it during many years in different businesses. With the birth of her third child she saw the need to abandon her work and dedicate herself to his care. 

Now, after thirteen years of suspending the activity, she wishes to begin anew with the goal of improving the quality of life for her family. This is why she finds herself applying for a loan to buy a sewing machine with which she will initiate her business project. She dreams of the possibility of having a great workshop with which she can convert herself into a source of direct employment.

loans.use: to buy a sewing machine.

loans.name: Wiseman

texts.en:
Wiseman is a business management student at the Maharishi Institute. Wiseman is 19 years old and was asked the following questions by a staff member of the Institute:

What do you study at the Maharishi Institute and what classes do you enjoy most?
“I am studying (for) a Bachelor of Business Administration degree. I enjoy most finance, accounting and business classes. I also enjoy consciousness-based education (CBE).”

What are your goals after graduation?
“After graduating, I would want to work as an auditor for any company, but at a later stage start my own company of chartered and accountancy. I would live all around the world in different countries. I would like to travel more and understand the doing of other businesses all around the world.”

Tell us about your background?
“I am the firstborn of a family of three boys and three girls, in which we are six. My father is a breadwinner; my mother is a housewife. We all are still in school. My hobbies are reading, writing and listening.”

What do you do in your spare time?
